title: Try splitting the number
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" have the property that when 1,000,063 is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the remainder is 63?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,000,063 = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" + 63,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So if 1,000,063  number divided by other number(n) to get remainder =63,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number should be multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and must be greater than 63,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So number of divisors for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = 7(7) = 49."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"now we have to exclude "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,4,5,8,16,32,10,20,25,40,50"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (since they are greater than 63),"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we get total number of values of n = 49 - 12 = 37."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice solution. It makes it so simple in understanding the problem. Thank you for posting it.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I thought the answer was 49. What I didn't realize was that there were twelve exclusions.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} 1000063 & \equiv 63 \pmod {n} \\ \implies 1000000 & \equiv 0 \pmod {n} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000000 = 2^6 5^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(6+1)(6+1) = 49"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Out of these 49 factors, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000063 \mod = \begin{cases} 63-n & \text{if }n < 63 \\ 63 & \text{if }n > 63 \end{cases} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since factors smaller than 63 are 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, and 5, 10, 20, 25, 40, 50, a total of 12.  Therefore, the number of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that gives a remainder of 63 is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"49-12=\boxed{37}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1,000,000 Coin Flips
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that we flip "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,000,000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" fair coins and obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" heads. Which event is more likely? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Source: Aha! Solutions by Martin Erickson","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{Probability}\left[x=500000,x\overset{\sim}{\sim}\text{BinomialDistribution}\left[1000000,\frac{1}{2}\right]\right]> \\ \text{Probability}\left[0<x<495000,x\overset{\sim}{\sim}\text{BinomialDistribution}\left[1000000,\frac{1}{2}\right]\right]
\Rightarrow \\ \text{True}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In fact the 495000 could be increased to 498422 and it would still be true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

100,000 points problem

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"first off.. i loved this problem, thanks to the creator for giving me such great experience.
start like this
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
\frac{3}{x-3}+\frac{5}{x-5}+\frac{17}{x-17}+\frac{19}{x-19}+4= x^2-11x\\
\frac{3}{x-3}+1+\frac{5}{x-5}+1+\frac{17}{x-17}+1+\frac{19}{x-19}+1= x^2-11x\\
\frac{x}{x-3}+\frac{x}{x-5}+\frac{x}{x-17}+\frac{x}{x-19}=x(x-11)\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
we get x=0 as a solution. now divide by x and put x=y+11
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{y+8}+\frac{1}{y-8}+\frac{1}{y+6}+\frac{1}{y-6}=y\\
\frac{2y}{y^2-64}+\frac{2y}{y^2-36}=y \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
y=0 ->x=11 is another solution. we divide again to get
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
\frac{2}{y^2-64}+\frac{2}{y^2-36}=1\\
2(y^2-36)+2(y^2-64)=(y^2-64)(y^2-36)\\
4y^2-200=y^4-100y^2+2304\\
y^4-104y^2+2504=0\\
y^2=52\pm \sqrt{200}\\
y=\pm\sqrt{52\pm \sqrt{200}}\\
x=11\pm\sqrt{52\pm \sqrt{200}}\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
we get that 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0,11,11\pm\sqrt{52\pm \sqrt{200}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
the required
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_{largest}=11+\sqrt{52+ \sqrt{200}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"11+52+200=\boxed{263}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100001-gon
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Dan and Sam play a game on a convex polygon of 100001 sides. Each one draws a diagonal on the polygon in his turn."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When someone draws a diagonal, it cannot have common points (except the vertices of the polygon) with other diagonals already drawn."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The game finishes when someone can't draw a diagonal on the polygon following the rules; that person is the loser. If Dan begins, who will win? This means, who has a winning strategy?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clarification:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" The diagonals of a polygon are straight lines that join non-adjacent vertices. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is the fourteenth problem of the set Winning Strategies."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When Dan draws a diagonal in the first turn, he divides the polygon in two convex polygons: one with an even number of sides and one with an odd number. Sam must split the even polygonal in half. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If in subsequent turns Dan plays in one half, Sam just mirror Dan's move in the other half, so Sam wins in the even polygon."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If Dan decides to play on the odd polygon, we're beginning the game again: he divides the polygon in two convex polygons, one with an even number of sides and one with an odd number. Anew, Sam wins in the even polygon."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As the polygon consists of a finite number of sides, after some turns, Dan will have splitted an odd polygon in a triangle and an even polygon (at least, a quadrilateral). Sam wins in the even polygon, and in a triangle nobody can draw a diagonal. Therefore, Sam wins."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As it is 1 odd sided polygon, any move would create 1 odd & 1 even sided."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"next move could either create  1 extra even or remove 1 even sided polygon. So we can see that on dan's move, there are always even number of even numbered polygons while on sam's move only odd number of even sided polygons will be there."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus for every move Sam will be able to draw a diagonal as every even sided polygon can be cut."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the sum of the prime factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000027"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Source: 2017 Duke Math Meet Team Round #3"}]}]}

title: 10000 diagonals
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let f(x) = the number of diagonals in a x-gon polygon"}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"find f(10000)"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let us consider one individual vertex. 
A diagonal is a line formed when that vertex and another point are joined. However, if a point is directly adjacent to it, the line formed will not be a diagonal (it will be an edge). Also, it is obvious that the point itself cannot be chosen (no line formed). Therefore a vertex will be formed between that vertex, and all but three (one on each side and the point itself) of the other vertices. This is true for all the vertices. Thus, "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)=x(x-3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (so far)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, connecting vertices A and B forms the same diagonal as connecting B and A. We are therefore counting each individual diagonals as two distinct diagonals, which is not true, so we must divide by 2. Therefore our function becomes "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)=1/2*x(x-3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and finally, "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(10,000)=49985000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Number of diagonals for a polygon with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" sides is given by: "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)= \frac{x(x-3)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
In this case, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=10000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)= \frac{x(x-3)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow f(10000)= \frac{10000\times (10000-3)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow f(10000)=\frac{10000\times 9997}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow f(10000)=\frac{99970000}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow f(10000)=49985000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So, number of diagonals is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed {49985000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"actually f(x) = x(x-3)/2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"then its vry easy to vertify that f(10000) = 10000 x 9997 / 2 = 49985000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10000 followers follow up problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume today is December 1st."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On Jun 1 Calvin had 5000 followers and the amount of followers he had doubled every 6 months.  Today, he has 10000."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I began brilliant with one follower on Jun 1 and now I have 500 followers as the amount of followers I had has been multiplied by 500 every 6 months."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assuming the rates at which we gain followers remains exactly constant, how many days after Dec. 1 will it be before I have as many followers as Calvin? Answer to two decimal places."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"All months have 30 days"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You may use a computer software"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Logic does not apply (by this I mean exclude the fact that I probably will never have as many followers as Calvin, base your calculations explicitly off of the information given)"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Calvin="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10000*2^{\frac{x}{180}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Me="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"500*500^{\frac{x}{180}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Setting these two equal to eachother we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"180\left(\dfrac{\log20}{\log250}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Wolfram alpha yields 97.66"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 10000th Palindrome
